fact_list.fact_text: Keep a safe following distance from the vehicle in front to allow enough room to stop safely if the vehicle in front stops abruptly.
Do not harass the vehicle in front by tailgating it.
Tailgating is a dangerous practice that could easily lead to an accident.
Flashing your headlights or blasting the horn at slower-moving vehicles in front is rude.
Always stop or park close to the edge of the road.
Always stop or park at places where you would not cause inconvenience to other road users.
Do not stop your vehicle under a shaded spot at a distance from a junction while waiting for the traffic signal to change.
Stopping under a shaded spot away from a junction while waiting for a traffic signal slows down traffic at the junction.
When parking in a parking lot, park parallel to and in the center of the lot to be considerate.
Wait for your turn when looking for a parking lot.
Jumping the queue or forcing your way into a parking lot when another vehicle is trying to enter is rude.
Do not drive if your vehicleâ€™s headlamps, tail-lamps, or direction indicators are not working.
Dip your headlights when following vehicles or facing oncoming vehicles to prevent dazzling other drivers.
Turn on headlights during daytime when visibility is poor to be seen and see more easily.
Give pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcyclists plenty of room as they might change direction suddenly.
Avoid sounding the horn near pedestrians as it might scare them, potentially causing an accident.
Do not obstruct pedestrians by stopping on the pedestrian crossing.
Slow down on wet roads near pedestrians and cyclists to avoid splashing them with water.
Passing a cyclist is unsafe; wait until it is safe.
Overtaking and cutting off cyclists is very dangerous.
Ensure there is ample room when overtaking cyclists and avoid sharply merging into lanes, especially if driving heavy or large vehicles.
Always check your blind spot before changing lanes, making turns, or moving from a stationary position.
Check for cyclists before opening the vehicle door.
Signal early to inform other road users and cyclists in advance of your intended direction.
Look out for cyclists and pedestrians when approaching road crossings.
Always stop to render assistance and exchange particulars when involved in an accident.
Do not expect cyclists to cycle very close to the left next to the kerb as obstacles like drain holes may cause them to lose balance.
Always be patient and do not rush or lose your cool on the road.
Do not show any provocative gestures when other drivers make mistakes or cause inconvenience; accidents are not deliberate.
Apologize if you have caused inconvenience to others, as this can soothe the other driver.
Driving safely and competently requires total involvement of most senses and awareness of the environment.
A good driver should interpret, anticipate, and act under adverse driving conditions.
